props.name: generated-by
props.value: Cybersecurity And Privacy Open Reference Datasets In OSCAL (CAPORDINO)

props.name: keywords
props.value: Critical infrastructure, cybersecurity, information security, information system, OSCAL, Open Security Controls Assessment Language, security functions, security requirements, system, system security

parties.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology

addr-lines: National Institute of Standards and Technology

parties.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology

addr-lines: National Institute of Standards and Technology

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: The organization's cybersecurity risk management strategy, expectations, and policy are established, communicated, and monitored

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The circumstances - mission, stakeholder expectations, dependencies, and legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements - surrounding the organization's cybersecurity risk management decisions are understood

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organizational mission is understood and informs cybersecurity risk management

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Share the organization's mission (e.g., through vision and mission statements, marketing, and service strategies) to provide a basis for identifying risks that may impede that mission

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Internal and external stakeholders are understood, and their needs and expectations regarding cybersecurity risk management are understood and considered

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify relevant internal stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., performance and risk expectations of officers, directors, and advisors; cultural expectations of employees)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify relevant external stakeholders and their cybersecurity-related expectations (e.g., privacy expectations of customers, business expectations of partnerships, compliance expectations of regulators, ethics expectations of society)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements regarding cybersecurity - including privacy and civil liberties obligations - are understood and managed

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Determine a process to track and manage legal and regulatory requirements regarding protection of individuals' information (e.g., Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, California Consumer Privacy Act, General Data Protection Regulation)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Determine a process to track and manage contractual requirements for cybersecurity management of supplier, customer, and partner information

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Align the organization's cybersecurity strategy with legal, regulatory, and contractual requirements

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Critical objectives, capabilities, and services that external stakeholders depend on or expect from the organization are understood and communicated

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish criteria for determining the criticality of capabilities and services as viewed by internal and external stakeholders

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Determine (e.g., from a business impact analysis) assets and business operations that are vital to achieving mission objectives and the potential impact of a loss (or partial loss) of such operations

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish and communicate resilience objectives (e.g., recovery time objectives) for delivering critical capabilities and services in various operating states (e.g., under attack, during recovery, normal operation)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Outcomes, capabilities, and services that the organization depends on are understood and communicated

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Create an inventory of the organization's dependencies on external resources (e.g., facilities, cloud-based hosting providers) and their relationships to organizational assets and business functions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify and document external dependencies that are potential points of failure for the organization's critical capabilities and services, and share that information with appropriate personnel

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Results of organization-wide cybersecurity risk management activities and performance are used to inform, improve, and adjust the risk management strategy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity risk management strategy outcomes are reviewed to inform and adjust strategy and direction

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Measure how well the risk management strategy and risk results have helped leaders make decisions and achieve organizational objectives

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Examine whether cybersecurity risk strategies that impede operations or innovation should be adjusted

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The cybersecurity risk management strategy is reviewed and adjusted to ensure coverage of organizational requirements and risks

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review audit findings to confirm whether the existing cybersecurity strategy has ensured compliance with internal and external requirements

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review the performance oversight of those in cybersecurity-related roles to determine whether policy changes are necessary

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review strategy in light of cybersecurity incidents

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organizational cybersecurity risk management performance is evaluated and reviewed for adjustments needed

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review key performance indicators (KPIs) to ensure that organization-wide policies and procedures achieve objectives

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review key risk indicators (KRIs) to identify risks the organization faces, including likelihood and potential impact

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Collect and communicate metrics on cybersecurity risk management with senior leadership

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established, communicated, and enforced

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is established based on organizational context, cybersecurity strategy, and priorities and is communicated and enforced

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Create, disseminate, and maintain an understandable, usable risk management policy with statements of management intent, expectations, and direction

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Periodically review policy and supporting processes and procedures to ensure that they align with risk management strategy objectives and priorities, as well as the high-level direction of the cybersecurity policy

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Require approval from senior management on policy

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Communicate cybersecurity risk management policy and supporting processes and procedures across the organization

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Require personnel to acknowledge receipt of policy when first hired, annually, and whenever policy is updated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Policy for managing cybersecurity risks is reviewed, updated, communicated, and enforced to reflect changes in requirements, threats, technology, and organizational mission

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Update policy based on periodic reviews of cybersecurity risk management results to ensure that policy and supporting processes and procedures adequately maintain risk at an acceptable level

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Provide a timeline for reviewing changes to the organization's risk environment (e.g., changes in risk or in the organization's mission objectives), and communicate recommended policy updates

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Update policy to reflect changes in legal and regulatory requirements

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Update policy to reflect changes in technology (e.g., adoption of artificial intelligence) and changes to the business (e.g., acquisition of a new business, new contract requirements)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization's priorities, constraints, risk tolerance and appetite statements, and assumptions are established, communicated, and used to support operational risk decisions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Risk management objectives are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Update near-term and long-term cybersecurity risk management objectives as part of annual strategic planning and when major changes occur

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish measurable objectives for cybersecurity risk management (e.g., manage the quality of user training, ensure adequate risk protection for industrial control systems)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Senior leaders agree about cybersecurity objectives and use them for measuring and managing risk and performance

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Risk appetite and risk tolerance statements are established, communicated, and maintained

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Determine and communicate risk appetite statements that convey expectations about the appropriate level of risk for the organization

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Translate risk appetite statements into specific, measurable, and broadly understandable risk tolerance statements

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Refine organizational objectives and risk appetite periodically based on known risk exposure and residual risk

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity risk management activities and outcomes are included in enterprise risk management processes

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Aggregate and manage cybersecurity risks alongside other enterprise risks (e.g., compliance, financial, operational, regulatory, reputational, safety)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Include cybersecurity risk managers in enterprise risk management planning

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish criteria for escalating cybersecurity risks within enterprise risk management

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Strategic direction that describes appropriate risk response options is established and communicated

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Specify criteria for accepting and avoiding cybersecurity risk for various classifications of data

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Determine whether to purchase cybersecurity insurance

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Document conditions under which shared responsibility models are acceptable (e.g., outsourcing certain cybersecurity functions, having a third party perform financial transactions on behalf of the organization, using public cloud-based services)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Lines of communication across the organization are established for cybersecurity risks, including risks from suppliers and other third parties

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Determine how to update senior executives, directors, and management on the organization's cybersecurity posture at agreed-upon intervals

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify how all departments across the organization - such as management, operations, internal auditors, legal, acquisition, physical security, and HR - will communicate with each other about cybersecurity risks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A standardized method for calculating, documenting, categorizing, and prioritizing cybersecurity risks is established and communicated

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish criteria for using a quantitative approach to cybersecurity risk analysis, and specify probability and exposure formulas

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Create and use templates (e.g., a risk register) to document cybersecurity risk information (e.g., risk description, exposure, treatment, and ownership)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish criteria for risk prioritization at the appropriate levels within the enterprise

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use a consistent list of risk categories to support integrating, aggregating, and comparing cybersecurity risks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Strategic opportunities (i.e., positive risks) are characterized and are included in organizational cybersecurity risk discussions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define and communicate guidance and methods for identifying opportunities and including them in risk discussions (e.g., strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats (SWOT) analysis)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify stretch goals and document them

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Calculate, document, and prioritize positive risks alongside negative risks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity roles, responsibilities, and authorities to foster accountability, performance assessment, and continuous improvement are established and communicated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organizational leadership is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk and fosters a culture that is risk-aware, ethical, and continually improving

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Leaders (e.g., directors) agree on their roles and responsibilities in developing, implementing, and assessing the organization's cybersecurity strategy

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Share leaders' expectations regarding a secure and ethical culture, especially when current events present the opportunity to highlight positive or negative examples of cybersecurity risk management

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Leaders direct the CISO to maintain a comprehensive cybersecurity risk strategy and review and update it at least annually and after major events

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Conduct reviews to ensure adequate authority and coordination among those responsible for managing cybersecurity risk

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Roles, responsibilities, and authorities related to cybersecurity risk management are established, communicated, understood, and enforced

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Document risk management roles and responsibilities in policy

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Document who is responsible and accountable for cybersecurity risk management activities and how those teams and individuals are to be consulted and informed

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Include cybersecurity responsibilities and performance requirements in personnel descriptions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Document performance goals for personnel with cybersecurity risk management responsibilities, and periodically measure performance to identify areas for improvement

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Clearly articulate cybersecurity responsibilities within operations, risk functions, and internal audit functions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Adequate resources are allocated commensurate with the cybersecurity risk strategy, roles, responsibilities, and policies

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Conduct periodic management reviews to ensure that those given cybersecurity risk management responsibilities have the necessary authority

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify resource allocation and investment in line with risk tolerance and response

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Provide adequate and sufficient people, process, and technical resources to support the cybersecurity strategy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Integrate cybersecurity risk management considerations into human resources processes (e.g., personnel screening, onboarding, change notification, offboarding)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Consider cybersecurity knowledge to be a positive factor in hiring, training, and retention decisions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Conduct background checks prior to onboarding new personnel for sensitive roles, and periodically repeat background checks for personnel with such roles

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define and enforce obligations for personnel to be aware of, adhere to, and uphold security policies as they relate to their roles

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, managed, monitored, and improved by organizational stakeholders

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, strategy, objectives, policies, and processes are established and agreed to by organizational stakeholders

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish a strategy that expresses the objectives of the cybersecurity supply chain risk management program

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Develop the cybersecurity supply chain risk management program, including a plan (with milestones), policies, and procedures that guide implementation and improvement of the program, and share the policies and procedures with the organizational stakeholders

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Develop and implement program processes based on the strategy, objectives, policies, and procedures that are agreed upon and performed by the organizational stakeholders

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish a cross-organizational mechanism that ensures alignment between functions that contribute to cybersecurity supply chain risk management, such as cybersecurity, IT, operations, legal, human resources, and engineering

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and partners are established, communicated, and coordinated internally and externally

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify one or more specific roles or positions that will be responsible and accountable for planning, resourcing, and executing cybersecurity supply chain risk management activities

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Document cybersecurity supply chain risk management roles and responsibilities in policy

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Create responsibility matrixes to document who will be responsible and accountable for cybersecurity supply chain risk management activities and how those teams and individuals will be consulted and informed

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Include cybersecurity supply chain risk management responsibilities and performance requirements in personnel descriptions to ensure clarity and improve accountability

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Document performance goals for personnel with cybersecurity risk management-specific responsibilities, and periodically measure them to demonstrate and improve performance

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Develop roles and responsibilities for suppliers, customers, and business partners to address shared responsibilities for applicable cybersecurity risks, and integrate them into organizational policies and applicable third-party agreements

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Internally communicate cybersecurity supply chain risk management roles and responsibilities for third parties

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish rules and protocols for information sharing and reporting processes between the organization and its suppliers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management is integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management, risk assessment, and improvement processes

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify areas of alignment and overlap with cybersecurity and enterprise risk management

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish integrated control sets for cybersecurity risk management and cybersecurity supply chain risk management

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Integrate cybersecurity supply chain risk management into improvement processes

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Escalate material cybersecurity risks in supply chains to senior management, and address them at the enterprise risk management level

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Suppliers are known and prioritized by criticality

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Develop criteria for supplier criticality based on, for example, the sensitivity of data processed or possessed by suppliers, the degree of access to the organization's systems, and the importance of the products or services to the organization's mission

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Keep a record of all suppliers, and prioritize suppliers based on the criticality criteria

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Requirements to address cybersecurity risks in supply chains are established, prioritized, and integrated into contracts and other types of agreements with suppliers and other relevant third parties

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish security requirements for suppliers, products, and services commensurate with their criticality level and potential impact if compromised

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Include all cybersecurity and supply chain requirements that third parties must follow and how compliance with the requirements may be verified in default contractual language

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define the rules and protocols for information sharing between the organization and its suppliers and sub-tier suppliers in agreements

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Manage risk by including security requirements in agreements based on their criticality and potential impact if compromised

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define security requirements in service-level agreements (SLAs) for monitoring suppliers for acceptable security performance throughout the supplier relationship lifecycle

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Contractually require suppliers to disclose cybersecurity features, functions, and vulnerabilities of their products and services for the life of the product or the term of service

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Contractually require suppliers to provide and maintain a current component inventory (e.g., software or hardware bill of materials) for critical products

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Contractually require suppliers to vet their employees and guard against insider threats

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Contractually require suppliers to provide evidence of performing acceptable security practices through, for example, self-attestation, conformance to known standards, certifications, or inspections

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Specify in contracts and other agreements the rights and responsibilities of the organization, its suppliers, and their supply chains, with respect to potential cybersecurity risks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Planning and due diligence are performed to reduce risks before entering into formal supplier or other third-party relationships

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Perform thorough due diligence on prospective suppliers that is consistent with procurement planning and commensurate with the level of risk, criticality, and complexity of each supplier relationship

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Assess the suitability of the technology and cybersecurity capabilities and the risk management practices of prospective suppliers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Conduct supplier risk assessments against business and applicable cybersecurity requirements

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Assess the authenticity, integrity, and security of critical products prior to acquisition and use

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The risks posed by a supplier, their products and services, and other third parties are understood, recorded, prioritized, assessed, responded to, and monitored over the course of the relationship

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Adjust assessment formats and frequencies based on the third party's reputation and the criticality of the products or services they provide

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Evaluate third parties' evidence of compliance with contractual cybersecurity requirements, such as self-attestations, warranties, certifications, and other artifacts

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor critical suppliers to ensure that they are fulfilling their security obligations throughout the supplier relationship lifecycle using a variety of methods and techniques, such as inspections, audits, tests, or other forms of evaluation

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor critical suppliers, services, and products for changes to their risk profiles, and reevaluate supplier criticality and risk impact accordingly

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Plan for unexpected supplier and supply chain-related interruptions to ensure business continuity

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Relevant suppliers and other third parties are included in incident planning, response, and recovery activities

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define and use rules and protocols for reporting incident response and recovery activities and the status between the organization and its suppliers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify and document the roles and responsibilities of the organization and its suppliers for incident response

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Include critical suppliers in incident response exercises and simulations

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define and coordinate crisis communication methods and protocols between the organization and its critical suppliers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Conduct collaborative lessons learned sessions with critical suppliers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Supply chain security practices are integrated into cybersecurity and enterprise risk management programs, and their performance is monitored throughout the technology product and service life cycle

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Policies and procedures require provenance records for all acquired technology products and services

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Periodically provide risk reporting to leaders about how acquired components are proven to be untampered and authentic

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Communicate regularly among cybersecurity risk managers and operations personnel about the need to acquire software patches, updates, and upgrades only from authenticated and trustworthy software providers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review policies to ensure that they require approved supplier personnel to perform maintenance on supplier products

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Policies and procedure require checking upgrades to critical hardware for unauthorized changes

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity supply chain risk management plans include provisions for activities that occur after the conclusion of a partnership or service agreement

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish processes for terminating critical relationships under both normal and adverse circumstances

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define and implement plans for component end-of-life maintenance support and obsolescence

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Verify that supplier access to organization resources is deactivated promptly when it is no longer needed

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Verify that assets containing the organization's data are returned or properly disposed of in a timely, controlled, and safe manner

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Develop and execute a plan for terminating or transitioning supplier relationships that takes supply chain security risk and resiliency into account

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Mitigate risks to data and systems created by supplier termination

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Manage data leakage risks associated with supplier termination

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: The organization's current cybersecurity risks are understood

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Assets (e.g., data, hardware, software, systems, facilities, services, people) that enable the organization to achieve business purposes are identified and managed consistent with their relative importance to organizational objectives and the organization's risk strategy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Inventories of hardware managed by the organization are maintained

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain inventories for all types of hardware, including IT, IoT, OT, and mobile devices

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Constantly monitor networks to detect new hardware and automatically update inventories

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Inventories of software, services, and systems managed by the organization are maintained

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain inventories for all types of software and services, including commercial-off-the-shelf, open-source, custom applications, API services, and cloud-based applications and services

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Constantly monitor all platforms, including containers and virtual machines, for software and service inventory changes

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain an inventory of the organization's systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Representations of the organization's authorized network communication and internal and external network data flows are maintained

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows within the organization's wired and wireless networks

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows between the organization and third parties

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain baselines of communication and data flows for the organization's infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS) usage

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain documentation of expected network ports, protocols, and services that are typically used among authorized systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Inventories of services provided by suppliers are maintained

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Inventory all external services used by the organization, including third-party infrastructure-as-a-service (IaaS), platform-as-a-service (PaaS), and software-as-a-service (SaaS) offerings; APIs; and other externally hosted application services

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Update the inventory when a new external service is going to be utilized to ensure adequate cybersecurity risk management monitoring of the organization's use of that service

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Assets are prioritized based on classification, criticality, resources, and impact on the mission

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define criteria for prioritizing each class of assets

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Apply the prioritization criteria to assets

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Track the asset priorities and update them periodically or when significant changes to the organization occur

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities for the entire workforce and third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) are established

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Inventories of data and corresponding metadata for designated data types are maintained

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain a list of the designated data types of interest (e.g., personally identifiable information, protected health information, financial account numbers, organization intellectual property, operational technology data)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Continuously discover and analyze ad hoc data to identify new instances of designated data types

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Assign data classifications to designated data types through tags or labels

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Track the provenance, data owner, and geolocation of each instance of designated data types

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Systems, hardware, software, services, and data are managed throughout their life cycles

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Integrate cybersecurity considerations throughout the life cycles of systems, hardware, software, and services

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Integrate cybersecurity considerations into product life cycles

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify unofficial uses of technology to meet mission objectives (i.e., shadow IT)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Periodically identify redundant systems, hardware, software, and services that unnecessarily increase the organization's attack surface

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Properly configure and secure systems, hardware, software, and services prior to their deployment in production

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Update inventories when systems, hardware, software, and services are moved or transferred within the organization

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Securely destroy stored data based on the organization's data retention policy using the prescribed destruction method, and keep and manage a record of the destructions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Securely sanitize data storage when hardware is being retired, decommissioned, reassigned, or sent for repairs or replacement

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Offer methods for destroying paper, storage media, and other physical forms of data storage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization’s role in the supply chain is identified and communicated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization’s place in critical infrastructure and its industry sector is identified and communicated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Priorities for organizational mission, objectives, and activities are established and communicated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Dependencies and critical functions for delivery of critical services are established

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Resilience requirements to support delivery of critical services are established for all operating states (e.g. under duress/attack, during recovery, normal operations)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organizational cybersecurity policy is established and communicated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity roles and responsibilities are coordinated and aligned with internal roles and external partners

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Legal and regulatory requirements regarding cybersecurity, including privacy and civil liberties obligations, are understood and managed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Governance and risk management processes address cybersecurity risks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Improvements to organizational cybersecurity risk management processes, procedures and activities are identified across all CSF Functions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Improvements are identified from evaluations

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Perform self-assessments of critical services that take current threats and TTPs into consideration

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Invest in third-party assessments or independent audits of the effectiveness of the organization's cybersecurity program to identify areas that need improvement

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Constantly evaluate compliance with selected cybersecurity requirements through automated means

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Improvements are identified from security tests and exercises, including those done in coordination with suppliers and relevant third parties

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify improvements for future incident response activities based on findings from incident response assessments (e.g., tabletop exercises and simulations, tests, internal reviews, independent audits)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify improvements for future business continuity, disaster recovery, and incident response activities based on exercises performed in coordination with critical service providers and product suppliers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Involve internal stakeholders (e.g., senior executives, legal department, HR) in security tests and exercises as appropriate

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Perform penetration testing to identify opportunities to improve the security posture of selected high-risk systems as approved by leadership

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Exercise contingency plans for responding to and recovering from the discovery that products or services did not originate with the contracted supplier or partner or were altered before receipt

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Collect and analyze performance metrics using security tools and services to inform improvements to the cybersecurity program

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Improvements are identified from execution of operational processes, procedures, and activities

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Conduct collaborative lessons learned sessions with suppliers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Annually review cybersecurity policies, processes, and procedures to take lessons learned into account

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use metrics to assess operational cybersecurity performance over time

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Incident response plans and other cybersecurity plans that affect operations are established, communicated, maintained, and improved

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish contingency plans (e.g., incident response, business continuity, disaster recovery) for responding to and recovering from adverse events that can interfere with operations, expose confidential information, or otherwise endanger the organization's mission and viability

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Include contact and communication information, processes for handling common scenarios, and criteria for prioritization, escalation, and elevation in all contingency plans

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Create a vulnerability management plan to identify and assess all types of vulnerabilities and to prioritize, test, and implement risk responses

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Communicate cybersecurity plans (including updates) to those responsible for carrying them out and to affected parties

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review and update all cybersecurity plans annually or when a need for significant improvements is identified

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The cybersecurity risk to the organization, assets, and individuals is understood by the organization

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Vulnerabilities in assets are identified, validated, and recorded

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use vulnerability management technologies to identify unpatched and misconfigured software

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Assess network and system architectures for design and implementation weaknesses that affect cybersecurity

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review, analyze, or test organization-developed software to identify design, coding, and default configuration vulnerabilities

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Assess facilities that house critical computing assets for physical vulnerabilities and resilience issues

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor sources of cyber threat intelligence for information on new vulnerabilities in products and services

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review processes and procedures for weaknesses that could be exploited to affect cybersecurity

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber threat intelligence is received from information sharing forums and sources

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Configure cybersecurity tools and technologies with detection or response capabilities to securely ingest cyber threat intelligence feeds

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Receive and review advisories from reputable third parties on current threat actors and their tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor sources of cyber threat intelligence for information on the types of vulnerabilities that emerging technologies may have

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Internal and external threats to the organization are identified and recorded

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use cyber threat intelligence to maintain awareness of the types of threat actors likely to target the organization and the TTPs they are likely to use

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Perform threat hunting to look for signs of threat actors within the environment

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Implement processes for identifying internal threat actors

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Potential impacts and likelihoods of threats exploiting vulnerabilities are identified and recorded

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Business leaders and cybersecurity risk management practitioners work together to estimate the likelihood and impact of risk scenarios and record them in risk registers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Enumerate the potential business impacts of unauthorized access to the organization's communications, systems, and data processed in or by those systems

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Account for the potential impacts of cascading failures for systems of systems

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Threats, vulnerabilities, likelihoods, and impacts are used to understand inherent risk and inform risk response prioritization

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Develop threat models to better understand risks to the data and identify appropriate risk responses

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Prioritize cybersecurity resource allocations and investments based on estimated likelihoods and impacts

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Risk responses are chosen, prioritized, planned, tracked, and communicated

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Apply the vulnerability management plan's criteria for deciding whether to accept, transfer, mitigate, or avoid risk

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Apply the vulnerability management plan's criteria for selecting compensating controls to mitigate risk

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Track the progress of risk response implementation (e.g., plan of action and milestones (POA&M), risk register, risk detail report)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use risk assessment findings to inform risk response decisions and actions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Communicate planned risk responses to affected stakeholders in priority order

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Changes and exceptions are managed, assessed for risk impact, recorded, and tracked

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Implement and follow procedures for the formal documentation, review, testing, and approval of proposed changes and requested exceptions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Document the possible risks of making or not making each proposed change, and provide guidance on rolling back changes

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Document the risks related to each requested exception and the plan for responding to those risks

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Periodically review risks that were accepted based upon planned future actions or milestones

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Processes for receiving, analyzing, and responding to vulnerability disclosures are established

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Conduct vulnerability information sharing between the organization and its suppliers following the rules and protocols defined in contracts

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Assign responsibilities and verify the execution of procedures for processing, analyzing the impact of, and responding to cybersecurity threat, vulnerability, or incident disclosures by suppliers, customers, partners, and government cybersecurity organizations

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The authenticity and integrity of hardware and software are assessed prior to acquisition and use

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Assess the authenticity and cybersecurity of critical technology products and services prior to acquisition and use

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Critical suppliers are assessed prior to acquisition

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Conduct supplier risk assessments against business and applicable cybersecurity requirements, including the supply chain

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Risk management processes are established, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Organizational risk tolerance is determined and clearly expressed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization’s determination of risk tolerance is informed by its role in critical infrastructure and sector specific risk analysis

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber supply chain risk management processes are identified, established, assessed, managed, and agreed to by organizational stakeholders

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Suppliers and third party partners of information systems, components, and services are identified, prioritized, and assessed using a cyber supply chain risk assessment process

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Contracts with suppliers and third-party partners are used to implement appropriate measures designed to meet the objectives of an organization’s cybersecurity program and Cyber Supply Chain Risk Management Plan.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Suppliers and third-party partners are routinely assessed using audits, test results, or other forms of evaluations to confirm they are meeting their contractual obligations.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Response and recovery planning and testing are conducted with suppliers and third-party providers

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: Safeguards to manage the organization's cybersecurity risks are used

controls.title: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control

props.name: label
props.value: Identity Management, Authentication, and Access Control (PR.AA)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access to physical and logical assets is limited to authorized users, services, and hardware and managed commensurate with the assessed risk of unauthorized access

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identities and credentials for authorized users, services, and hardware are managed by the organization

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Initiate requests for new access or additional access for employees, contractors, and others, and track, review, and fulfill the requests, with permission from system or data owners when needed

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Issue, manage, and revoke cryptographic certificates and identity tokens, cryptographic keys (i.e., key management), and other credentials

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Select a unique identifier for each device from immutable hardware characteristics or an identifier securely provisioned to the device

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Physically label authorized hardware with an identifier for inventory and servicing purposes

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials based on the context of interactions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Verify a person's claimed identity at enrollment time using government-issued identity credentials (e.g., passport, visa, driver's license)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Issue a different credential for each person (i.e., no credential sharing)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users, services, and hardware are authenticated

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Require multifactor authentication

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Enforce policies for the minimum strength of passwords, PINs, and similar authenticators

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Periodically reauthenticate users, services, and hardware based on risk (e.g., in zero trust architectures)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Ensure that authorized personnel can access accounts essential for protecting safety under emergency conditions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identity assertions are protected, conveyed, and verified

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Protect identity assertions that are used to convey authentication and user information through single sign-on systems

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Protect identity assertions that are used to convey authentication and user information between federated systems

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Implement standards-based approaches for identity assertions in all contexts, and follow all guidance for the generation (e.g., data models, metadata), protection (e.g., digital signing, encryption), and verification (e.g., signature validation) of identity assertions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access permissions, entitlements, and authorizations are defined in a policy, managed, enforced, and reviewed, and incorporate the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review logical and physical access privileges periodically and whenever someone changes roles or leaves the organization, and promptly rescind privileges that are no longer needed

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Take attributes of the requester and the requested resource into account for authorization decisions (e.g., geolocation, day/time, requester endpoint's cyber health)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Restrict access and privileges to the minimum necessary (e.g., zero trust architecture)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Periodically review the privileges associated with critical business functions to confirm proper separation of duties

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical access to assets is managed, monitored, and enforced commensurate with risk

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use security guards, security cameras, locked entrances, alarm systems, and other physical controls to monitor facilities and restrict access

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Employ additional physical security controls for areas that contain high-risk assets

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Escort guests, vendors, and other third parties within areas that contain business-critical assets

controls.title: Identity Management, Authentication and Access Control

props.name: label
props.value: Identity Management, Authentication and Access Control (PR.AC)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical access to assets is managed and protected

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Remote access is managed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Network integrity is protected (e.g., network segregation, network segmentation)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Identities are proofed and bound to credentials and asserted in interactions

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals’ security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization's personnel are provided with cybersecurity awareness and training so that they can perform their cybersecurity-related tasks

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform general tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Provide basic cybersecurity awareness and training to employees, contractors, partners, suppliers, and all other users of the organization's non-public resources

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Train personnel to recognize social engineering attempts and other common attacks, report attacks and suspicious activity, comply with acceptable use policies, and perform basic cyber hygiene tasks (e.g., patching software, choosing passwords, protecting credentials)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Explain the consequences of cybersecurity policy violations, both to individual users and the organization as a whole

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Periodically assess or test users on their understanding of basic cybersecurity practices

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Require annual refreshers to reinforce existing practices and introduce new practices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Individuals in specialized roles are provided with awareness and training so that they possess the knowledge and skills to perform relevant tasks with cybersecurity risks in mind

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Identify the specialized roles within the organization that require additional cybersecurity training, such as physical and cybersecurity personnel, finance personnel, senior leadership, and anyone with access to business-critical data

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Provide role-based cybersecurity awareness and training to all those in specialized roles, including contractors, partners, suppliers, and other third parties

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Periodically assess or test users on their understanding of cybersecurity practices for their specialized roles

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Require annual refreshers to reinforce existing practices and introduce new practices

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Third-party stakeholders (e.g., suppliers, customers, partners) understand their roles and responsibilities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Senior executives understand their roles and responsibilities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Physical and cybersecurity personnel understand their roles and responsibilities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-at-rest are protected

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of stored data in files, databases, virtual machine disk images, container images, and other resources

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use full disk encryption to protect data stored on user endpoints

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Confirm the integrity of software by validating signatures

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Restrict the use of removable media to prevent data exfiltration

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Physically secure removable media containing unencrypted sensitive information, such as within locked offices or file cabinets

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-transit are protected

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use encryption, digital signatures, and cryptographic hashes to protect the confidentiality and integrity of network communications

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Automatically encrypt or block outbound emails and other communications that contain sensitive data, depending on the data classification

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Block access to personal email, file sharing, file storage services, and other personal communications applications and services from organizational systems and networks

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Prevent reuse of sensitive data from production environments (e.g., customer records) in development, testing, and other non-production environments

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Assets are formally managed throughout removal, transfers, and disposition

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protections against data leaks are implemented

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The development and testing environment(s) are separate from the production environment

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify hardware integrity

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The confidentiality, integrity, and availability of data-in-use are protected

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Remove data that must remain confidential (e.g., from processors and memory) as soon as it is no longer needed

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Protect data in use from access by other users and processes of the same platform

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backups of data are created, protected, maintained, and tested

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Continuously back up critical data in near-real-time, and back up other data frequently at agreed-upon schedules

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Test backups and restores for all types of data sources at least annually

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Securely store some backups offline and offsite so that an incident or disaster will not damage them

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Enforce geographic separation and geolocation restrictions for data backup storage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A baseline configuration of information technology/industrial control systems is created and maintained incorporating security principles (e.g. concept of least functionality)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A System Development Life Cycle to manage systems is implemented

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Configuration change control processes are in place

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Backups of information are conducted, maintained, and tested

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Policy and regulations regarding the physical operating environment for organizational assets are met

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Data is destroyed according to policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Protection processes are improved

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Effectiveness of protection technologies is shared

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Response plans (Incident Response and Business Continuity) and recovery plans (Incident Recovery and Disaster Recovery) are in place and managed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Response and recovery plans are tested

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cybersecurity is included in human resources practices (e.g., deprovisioning, personnel screening)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Security architectures are managed with the organization's risk strategy to protect asset confidentiality, integrity, and availability, and organizational resilience

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Networks and environments are protected from unauthorized logical access and usage

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Logically segment organization networks and cloud-based platforms according to trust boundaries and platform types (e.g., IT, IoT, OT, mobile, guests), and permit required communications only between segments

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Logically segment organization networks from external networks, and permit only necessary communications to enter the organization's networks from the external networks

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Implement zero trust architectures to restrict network access to each resource to the minimum necessary

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Check the cyber health of endpoints before allowing them to access and use production resources

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The organization's technology assets are protected from environmental threats

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Protect organizational equipment from known environmental threats, such as flooding, fire, wind, and excessive heat and humidity

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Include protection from environmental threats and provisions for adequate operating infrastructure in requirements for service providers that operate systems on the organization's behalf

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mechanisms are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Avoid single points of failure in systems and infrastructure

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use load balancing to increase capacity and improve reliability

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use high-availability components like redundant storage and power supplies to improve system reliability

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Adequate resource capacity to ensure availability is maintained

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor usage of storage, power, compute, network bandwidth, and other resources

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Forecast future needs, and scale resources accordingly

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Maintenance and repair of organizational assets are performed and logged, with approved and controlled tools

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Remote maintenance of organizational assets is approved, logged, and performed in a manner that prevents unauthorized access

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The hardware, software (e.g., firmware, operating systems, applications), and services of physical and virtual platforms are managed consistent with the organization's risk strategy to protect their confidentiality, integrity, and availability

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Configuration management practices are established and applied

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Establish, test, deploy, and maintain hardened baselines that enforce the organization's cybersecurity policies and provide only essential capabilities (i.e., principle of least functionality)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review all default configuration settings that may potentially impact cybersecurity when installing or upgrading software

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor implemented software for deviations from approved baselines

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Software is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Perform routine and emergency patching within the timeframes specified in the vulnerability management plan

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Update container images, and deploy new container instances to replace rather than update existing instances

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Replace end-of-life software and service versions with supported, maintained versions

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Uninstall and remove unauthorized software and services that pose undue risks

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Uninstall and remove any unnecessary software components (e.g., operating system utilities) that attackers might misuse

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define and implement plans for software and service end-of-life maintenance support and obsolescence

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Hardware is maintained, replaced, and removed commensurate with risk

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Replace hardware when it lacks needed security capabilities or when it cannot support software with needed security capabilities

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Define and implement plans for hardware end-of-life maintenance support and obsolescence

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Perform hardware disposal in a secure, responsible, and auditable manner

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Log records are generated and made available for continuous monitoring

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Configure all operating systems, applications, and services (including cloud-based services) to generate log records

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Configure log generators to securely share their logs with the organization's logging infrastructure systems and services

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Configure log generators to record the data needed by zero-trust architectures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Installation and execution of unauthorized software are prevented

parts.name: example
parts.prose: When risk warrants it, restrict software execution to permitted products only or deny the execution of prohibited and unauthorized software

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Verify the source of new software and the software's integrity before installing it

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Configure platforms to use only approved DNS services that block access to known malicious domains

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Configure platforms to allow the installation of organization-approved software only

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Secure software development practices are integrated, and their performance is monitored throughout the software development life cycle

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Protect all components of organization-developed software from tampering and unauthorized access

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Secure all software produced by the organization, with minimal vulnerabilities in their releases

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Maintain the software used in production environments, and securely dispose of software once it is no longer needed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Audit/log records are determined, documented, implemented, and reviewed in accordance with policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Removable media is protected and its use restricted according to policy

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Communications and control networks are protected

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Mechanisms (e.g., failsafe, load balancing, hot swap) are implemented to achieve resilience requirements in normal and adverse situations

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: Possible cybersecurity attacks and compromises are found and analyzed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events are analyzed to characterize the events and detect cybersecurity incidents

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: A baseline of network operations and expected data flows for users and systems is established and managed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Potentially adverse events are analyzed to better understand associated activities

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use security information and event management (SIEM) or other tools to continuously monitor log events for known malicious and suspicious activity

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Utilize up-to-date cyber threat intelligence in log analysis tools to improve detection accuracy and characterize threat actors, their methods, and indicators of compromise

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Regularly conduct manual reviews of log events for technologies that cannot be sufficiently monitored through automation

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use log analysis tools to generate reports on their findings

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information is correlated from multiple sources

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Constantly transfer log data generated by other sources to a relatively small number of log servers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use event correlation technology (e.g., SIEM) to collect information captured by multiple sources

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Utilize cyber threat intelligence to help correlate events among log sources

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The estimated impact and scope of adverse events are understood

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use SIEMs or other tools to estimate impact and scope, and review and refine the estimates

parts.name: example
parts.prose: A person creates their own estimates of impact and scope

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Incident alert thresholds are established

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information on adverse events is provided to authorized staff and tools

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use cybersecurity software to generate alerts and provide them to the security operations center (SOC), incident responders, and incident response tools

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Incident responders and other authorized personnel can access log analysis findings at all times

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Automatically create and assign tickets in the organization's ticketing system when certain types of alerts occur

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Manually create and assign tickets in the organization's ticketing system when technical staff discover indicators of compromise

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Cyber threat intelligence and other contextual information are integrated into the analysis

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Securely provide cyber threat intelligence feeds to detection technologies, processes, and personnel

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Securely provide information from asset inventories to detection technologies, processes, and personnel

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Rapidly acquire and analyze vulnerability disclosures for the organization's technologies from suppliers, vendors, and third-party security advisories

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Incidents are declared when adverse events meet the defined incident criteria

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Apply incident criteria to known and assumed characteristics of activity in order to determine whether an incident should be declared

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Take known false positives into account when applying incident criteria

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Assets are monitored to find anomalies, indicators of compromise, and other potentially adverse events

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Networks and network services are monitored to find potentially adverse events

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor DNS, BGP, and other network services for adverse events

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor wired and wireless networks for connections from unauthorized endpoints

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor facilities for unauthorized or rogue wireless networks

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Compare actual network flows against baselines to detect deviations

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor network communications to identify changes in security postures for zero trust purposes

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The physical environment is monitored to find potentially adverse events

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor logs from physical access control systems (e.g., badge readers) to find unusual access patterns (e.g., deviations from the norm) and failed access attempts

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review and monitor physical access records (e.g., from visitor registration, sign-in sheets)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor physical access controls (e.g., locks, latches, hinge pins, alarms) for signs of tampering

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor the physical environment using alarm systems, cameras, and security guards

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel activity and technology usage are monitored to find potentially adverse events

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use behavior analytics software to detect anomalous user activity to mitigate insider threats

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor logs from logical access control systems to find unusual access patterns and failed access attempts

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Continuously monitor deception technology, including user accounts, for any usage

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Malicious code is detected

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Unauthorized mobile code is detected

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: External service provider activities and services are monitored to find potentially adverse events

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor remote and onsite administration and maintenance activities that external providers perform on organizational systems

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor activity from cloud-based services, internet service providers, and other service providers for deviations from expected behavior

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Monitoring for unauthorized personnel, connections, devices, and software is performed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Vulnerability scans are performed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Computing hardware and software, runtime environments, and their data are monitored to find potentially adverse events

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor email, web, file sharing, collaboration services, and other common attack vectors to detect malware, phishing, data leaks and exfiltration, and other adverse events

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor authentication attempts to identify attacks against credentials and unauthorized credential reuse

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor software configurations for deviations from security baselines

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Monitor hardware and software for signs of tampering

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Use technologies with a presence on endpoints to detect cyber health issues (e.g., missing patches, malware infections, unauthorized software), and redirect the endpoints to a remediation environment before access is authorized

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Roles and responsibilities for detection are well defined to ensure accountability

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Detection activities comply with all applicable requirements

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Detection processes are tested

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Event detection information is communicated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Detection processes are continuously improved

parts.name: overview
parts.prose: Actions regarding a detected cybersecurity incident are taken

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Investigations are conducted to ensure effective response and support forensics and recovery activities

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Notifications from detection systems are investigated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The impact of the incident is understood

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Analysis is performed to establish what has taken place during an incident and the root cause of the incident

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Determine the sequence of events that occurred during the incident and which assets and resources were involved in each event

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Attempt to determine what vulnerabilities, threats, and threat actors were directly or indirectly involved in the incident

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Analyze the incident to find the underlying, systemic root causes

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Check any cyber deception technology for additional information on attacker behavior

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Incidents are categorized consistent with response plans

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Processes are established to receive, analyze and respond to vulnerabilities disclosed to the organization from internal and external sources (e.g. internal testing, security bulletins, or security researchers)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Actions performed during an investigation are recorded, and the records' integrity and provenance are preserved

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Require each incident responder and others (e.g., system administrators, cybersecurity engineers) who perform incident response tasks to record their actions and make the record immutable

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Require the incident lead to document the incident in detail and be responsible for preserving the integrity of the documentation and the sources of all information being reported

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Incident data and metadata are collected, and their integrity and provenance are preserved

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Collect, preserve, and safeguard the integrity of all pertinent incident data and metadata (e.g., data source, date/time of collection) based on evidence preservation and chain-of-custody procedures

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: An incident's magnitude is estimated and validated

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Review other potential targets of the incident to search for indicators of compromise and evidence of persistence

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Automatically run tools on targets to look for indicators of compromise and evidence of persistence

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Response activities are coordinated with internal and external stakeholders as required by laws, regulations, or policies

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Personnel know their roles and order of operations when a response is needed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Internal and external stakeholders are notified of incidents

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Follow the organization's breach notification procedures after discovering a data breach incident, including notifying affected customers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Notify business partners and customers of incidents in accordance with contractual requirements

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Notify law enforcement agencies and regulatory bodies of incidents based on criteria in the incident response plan and management approval

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Information is shared with designated internal and external stakeholders

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Securely share information consistent with response plans and information sharing agreements

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Voluntarily share information about an attacker's observed TTPs, with all sensitive data removed, with an Information Sharing and Analysis Center (ISAC)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Notify HR when malicious insider activity occurs

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Regularly update senior leadership on the status of major incidents

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Follow the rules and protocols defined in contracts for incident information sharing between the organization and its suppliers

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Coordinate crisis communication methods between the organization and its critical suppliers

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Coordination with stakeholders occurs consistent with response plans

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Voluntary information sharing occurs with external stakeholders to achieve broader cybersecurity situational awareness

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Response plans incorporate lessons learned

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Response strategies are updated

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Responses to detected cybersecurity incidents are managed

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: The incident response plan is executed in coordination with relevant third parties once an incident is declared

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Detection technologies automatically report confirmed incidents

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Request incident response assistance from the organization's incident response outsourcer

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Designate an incident lead for each incident

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Initiate execution of additional cybersecurity plans as needed to support incident response (for example, business continuity and disaster recovery)

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Incident reports are triaged and validated

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Preliminarily review incident reports to confirm that they are cybersecurity-related and necessitate incident response activities

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Apply criteria to estimate the severity of an incident

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Incidents are categorized and prioritized

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Further review and categorize incidents based on the type of incident (e.g., data breach, ransomware, DDoS, account compromise)

parts.name: example
parts.prose: Prioritize incidents based on their scope, likely impact, and time-critical nature

parts.name: example
